javanews.object.table
Class GenericTable

java.lang.Object
  javax.swing.table.AbstractTableModel
      javanews.object.table.GenericTable
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, javax.swing.table.TableModel
Direct Known Subclasses:
LinkTable
public class GenericTable
extends javax.swing.table.AbstractTableModel

This class is used to contain data for tables. All tables used in this application use this class for data storage and retrieval.

Version:
1.000
Author:
Alex Harris (email: Alexander.J.Harris(at)btinternet.com)
See Also:

Constructor Detail

GenericTable

public GenericTable()
Creates a new instance of the class and initialises the table with some default data values. These default values are in a one column Vector with five rows (New Data To Be Displayed Here #n). These can be used if needed for testing but should be overwritten within the application on first use. Therefore the first method called on a new instance of this class must be setData() rather than addRow().

See Also:
Vector, addRow(java.lang.Object[]), setData(java.util.Vector), setData(java.util.Vector, java.util.Vector)

setData

public void setData(java.util.Vector columns,
                    java.util.Vector rows)
Replaces the currently stored values in the table with the new arguments.

The columns Vector must contain a list of Strings while the rows can contain any object providing that the entries in one column match the type of those above and below it in the table.

Parameters:
columns - A Vector contain the names of the columns stored as Strings
rows - A Vector containing an array of entries to be stored in the table rows
See Also:
Vector

setData

public void setData(java.util.Vector rows)
Replaces the currently held rows with the contents of the supplied argument.

If the table has already been defined then this must have an equal number of columns to the number of column headers though the types may vary from those previously stored in the table.

Parameters:
rows - The new table rows to be stored
See Also:
Vector

addRow

public void addRow(java.lang.Object[] aNewRow)
Adds a new row to the table containing the table rows. The supplied Object array must be in the same order as those already within the table otherwise the entry won't display correctly.

Parameters:
aNewRow - The new row to be added

removeRow

public void removeRow(int x)
Used to remove a particular row from the table model.

Parameters:
x - The row number to be removed.

setEditableColumns

public void setEditableColumns(int[] editableColumns)
Defines the columns within the table which are editable to those contained within the array. If the table is completely uneditable then this method shouldn't be used or the argument should be set to null or an empty array. The columns whose index is included in the array is then set to editable. This means that if a whole table is set to editable then all indices should be contained within the array from 0 to size-1. The entries may be non-sequential and unordered.

Parameters:
editableColumns -

isCellEditable

public boolean isCellEditable(int row,
                              int col)
Returns a boolean value representing whether the column can be edited or not.

Specified by:
isCellEditable in interface javax.swing.table.TableModel
Overrides:

Parameters:
row - This is used internally by Java and not of importance to the functioning of the method.
col - This is the (zero-based) column index that is being queried.
Returns:
Whether or not the column contents can be edited.
